terms.definition: Product Requirements Document - an internal document that outlines what a product should accomplish for users without defining specific implementation details
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides self-service support to users
A support model where customers can find answers and solve problems independently without contacting support staff
The visual elements and interactive components through which users interact with a software application or system
Keep It Simple, Stupid - a design principle emphasizing simplicity and avoiding unnecessary complexity
Unique Selling Points - distinctive features or benefits that differentiate a product from competitors in the market
A lightweight markup language that uses plain text formatting syntax to create structured documents
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code, allowing teams to collaborate and maintain document history
Search Engine Optimization - the practice of optimizing content to improve visibility and ranking in search engine results
Enhanced search results that display additional information like ratings, prices, or structured data beyond standard text listings
The consistent personality and style of communication that reflects a brand's character in written content
Fictional characters created to represent different user types and their needs, behaviors, and goals when using a product
The process of adapting content for different languages, cultures, and regional markets beyond simple translation
The overall perception and interaction a customer has with a company across all touchpoints and stages of their journey
Specialized writing that explains complex technical information, processes, or products in a clear and accessible manner
